head.hi: M R. K I N G.

div.p: IT was a custom with the Grecian Fishermen of old, when they had escaped any danger at sea, to dedicate their little skiffs to whatever Tutelary Being they attributed its preservation: there is nothing more certain, than that the ABSENT MAN is chiefly, was I not the Author myself, perhaps, I might say wholly, indebted, for its success, to your excellent performance; it is therefore, with great pleasure I take this method of expressing my obligations to you.

Indeed, when I consider your puncituality in attending the rehearsals of this little piece, though out of the common business of the theatre; and the care you took, not only to be perfect yourself, but that it should be, in every respect, produced as complete as possible; I cannot help congratulating all our present writers on the stage, on the acquisition of a performer of such uncommon merit; and so great a favorite with the public; who, they may be assured, will consider their advantage and reputation, as well as his own; and do their pieces, at least, all the justice they are capable of receiving.

Had I an inclination to indulge myself in the dedicatory style, I might now tell you, with truth, that few men have filled so many characters with the same propriety that you have; but I leave this to some newspaper essayist, who might be fond of playing upon meanings and words; and vary your appearance upon the theatre how you please, I will venture to say, your acquaintance in private life, will always find you an honest, a sensible and a gentleman like man.

I am, Sir
with great esteem,
your obliged,
humble servant.

div.head: P R E F A C E.
div.p: THIS farce was written some years ago, since which time it has lain by the author, without being offered to the stage; nor should he have ventured it there at all, but to serve Mr. Holland at his benefit; upon which occasion, he thought the public, through favor to so deserving a performer would be willing to be pleased with any thing.
The event has greatly exceeded his hopes; the farce was not only received with general approbation the first night, but that sort of approbation which a writer may depend upon with greatest safety.

p.quote: "For smiles are honest when the hands are not"

div.p:
And on the second night, it met with marks of favour still more manifest. The Absent Man play was performed earlier in 1768 and seems to have garnered mixed results from critics. Volume 25 of The Critical Review, Or, Annals of Literature (1768) by W. Simpkin and R. Marshall write: "To render the character of an Absent Man entertaining on the stage, much more is required, and might have been expected, from a writer than a transcript from a writer than a transcript from Bruyere: his Menalcas is a caricature from Theophrastus whose original draught itself is much less pleasing, natural, and dramatic, than the Parson Adams of our inimitable Fielding." Coversely, the 1768 The Monthly Review, or Literary Journal by Several Hands writes rather curtly: "A laughable entertainment enough."
This engaged the author to look over it with greater care than he had before done, and having heightened some places where he thought it most deficient, he now submits it to the public, in a form, in which, he hopes it will not utterly displease, though it is needless to say that things of this kind have their principal merit in representation.

Regnard one of the most famous French comic poets, ranked by his countrymen next to Moliere, has written a play of five acts upon this subject, called, le DISTRAIT how ever, exclusive of their great disparity in merit; no two pieces can be less alike than that, and the ABSENT MAN; atleast, where the materials have been drawn from the same source. The DISTRAIT of Regnard is exactly the Menalcas of La Bruyere's characters, a few things only left out, which, though possessed of a pleasant extravagance in recital, would be too absurd for actual representation; the hint of the ABSENT MAN, and no more, is taken from the same character of Menalcas, translated in one of the numbers of the Spectator; with the assistance of which, if the present writer has been able to produce a laughable farce, it is all he aimed at, and he pretends to no more praise than such a trifling composition may deserve.

prologue.head: P R O L O G U E.

lg.l: Ere the curtain draws up, lift a little to me:
Are you all in a very good humour? Let's see;
Good humour you have, howe'er you come by it,
And I'm glad to my soul; for, by Jove, we shall try it.
Our farce is so very a farce, I'm in doubt,
If the pit and the boxes, will suffer it out;
But when we're in danger of such a mishap,
My dear friends above, drown their hiss in a clap;
And if you are pleas'd with our farcical man,
In spite of their airs, laugh as loud as you can.
To give you a sketch, now, by way of portraying,
His character's this&emdash;pray observe what I'm saying:
An odd kind of whimsical, blundering being,
Who has ears without hearing, and eyes without seeing;
Takes things by all handles, except by the right,
Ask a question in black, he answers in white.
Yes for no, no for yes; confuses, mistakes;
All he does so like dreaming, you'd scarce think he wakes.
Suppose to back-gammon my gentleman falls,
Box and dice in his hand, for some water he calls;
'Tis brought in a tumbler, when pop, in a trice,
He throws out the liquor, and swallows the dice.
Hard set are poor bards for your pleasures to cater,
And thus one provides for you, from the Spectator;
From volume the first, page three hundred and nine,
Number seventy-seven, he takes his design;
Let that be his sanction for what you behold:
Can the figure be had from so perfect a mold?
'Tis polish'd and varnish'd as well as he's able,
And he hopes you'll find something like conduct and fable.
Yet still this curst absence-in short here's the thing,
lf the character hits, thence his actions all spring;
And nought will disgust you, and nought will alarm you,
You'll takee ev'ry blunder, his follies will charm you;
But if&emdash;Gad we're all in a terrible fright,
So, begging for mercy, I wish you good night.

div.head: Scene I
div.stage: Shatterbrain'sLodgings. A Dressing-Table, with a Glass, &c. Frank asleep in a Chair. Landlady enters in a hurry.

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: Mr. Frank-Mr. Frank!

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: What's the matter?

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: Rouse, rouse, man!

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Is my master come home?

sp.speaker: Land
Frank
sp.p: Yaw&emdash;have I slept long?

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: You are asleep still, one would think&emdash;I tell you there is your master's father-in-law that is to be, come to fetch him away!

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: My master's father-in-law that is to be, come to fetch him away!

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: Ay.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Well&emdash;what shall we do?

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: Nay, I don't know&emdash;I come to ask you.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: If I was not acquainted with my master now, I should naturally conclude that the had either hanged, or drown'd himself in order to aviod being married.

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: Oh, he's a sad gentleman!

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: He is a little out of the way sometimes, indeed.

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: But the doctor waits&emdash;what excuse will you make him?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Why none&emdash;I remember it was a maxim with an attorney I once served, always to tell the truth&emdash;when a lie could not serve his purpose better &emdash;and I think we must e'en follow his example, at present.

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: Then I'll run down again, tho' I make a strange dirty figure. (Looking at herself in the Glass.) Lord! How I'm alter'd withiin these twelve years.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: I will but rub my eyes, and follow you.

sp.speaker: Frank

stage.hi: standing silent for some time, falls into an immoderate fit of Laughter.

sp.p: Well, if ever I (laughs again.)If ever I heard the likes of this since I was born, I wish I may be married to a woman of three-score, with the constitution of a girl of sixteen&emdash;Why it will be the general hoke of the whole town&emdash;that a man, (Laughs again) that a man should be such a&emdash;but stay&emdash;I'll tell the story to myself, and try how it will be found&emdash;Doctor Gruel, a physicial of noted worth and eminence, comes to a certain gentleman, Mr. Shatterbrain by name; and on account of an ancient friendship subsisting between thier families, and for some other reasons, which shal be nameless, offers him his only daughter for a wife&emdash;Mr. Shatterbrain accepts the proposal, and, in short, the happy day arrives, in which he is to be put in possession of the amiable object; when, behold you, the Doctor coming to call on his destined son-in-law, presto, pass and gone, the bird is flown; my gentleman is not to be found&emdash; He took himself off the same morning about seven o'clock&emdash;and nobody can tell what is become of him&emdash;it will never do&emdash;But hark! the Doctor is marching up staris&emdash;perhaps he may be able to give a physical reason for this.

div.head: Scene III
div.stage: Frank, Doctor Gruel, Landlady.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: So young man, where's your master?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Really, sir, I don't know.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: When will he come in?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Upon my word, sir, I can't tell.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Did he say nothing to you when he was going out?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Not a syllable, sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Nor to you, Madam?

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: Nor to me sir, as I'm a Christian.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Mercy on us, I suppose you know what engagements he had upon his hands this evening>

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Yes, sure, sir, very well, and I thought he had known it himself; but it seems I was mistaken.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Seriously, I am afraid some accident has happened to him

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: No sir, I don't believe any accident has happened to him.

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: Nor I niether, sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: What's your opinion then?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: I believe I need not tell you, sir, that my master is, one or other,the most absent man this day upon the case of the earth

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Truly I have opten heard him remarked for it; nay, I have myself taken notice of several glaring instances of it in him; but, that is a failing he will soon get the better of when his thoughts are properly employed; and matrimony&emdash;

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Will in all likelyhood perfectly cure him. 'tis granted, sir, matrimony is without a doubt an excellent remedy, in such distempers; a kind of manna and cream of tartat; a mixture of sweet and sour; wonderfully adapted to purge the mind of it's gross humours, and reduce the understanding to a perfect regularity of constitution.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: A good comical fellow this.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: But you cannot expect that the patient should recover, sir, before you have administer'd the remedy you intend to prescribe for his disease: therefore, you must not be surprised if my master happens to labour under a very violent fit of his out of the way malady, at this present moment.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: How do you mean?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Neither more, nor less, than that he has forgot he was to me married to your daughter to night, sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Forgot!

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: As sure as he can be he as Doctor.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Ay, sir, forgot&emdash;and giving the reins to his wild imagination, suffer'd it to run away with him the Lord knows whither. Why, sir, when he is in the forgetting mood, his memory is a perfect sieve &emdash;Any thing will fall thro' it&emdash;I have known him forget his own name before now.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: I am unwillig to think my friend Shatterbrain design'd to affront me&emdash;But if his memory was a seive, to which you compare it, that only yields a passage to minuter particles, while the more gross remain behind&emdash;And an affair of consequence, like&emdash;

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Lord, sir!, I could tell you such stories of See relevant passage from Rowe, LaBruyere (1713): difficulty&emdash;for instance, the other day, he was sitting in a coffee-house, when a fly which had buzz'd about him a good while, and he was watching an opportunity to kill, unluckily settled upon the cheek of a person who stood near him&emdash;Ha! says he, I believe I have you now; and with that, Sir, he up with his hand, and hit the poor gentleman such a confounded slap, as made the room ring again; one started, the other stared, in short, swords were drawn, and the cafe would infalliably have been transferred to Hyde Park, had not the acquaintance on both sides interposed; so he begged pardon, confessed he did not know what he was doing; it ended in a hearty laugh, and the general astonishment of the whole company.

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: About a fortnight ago, sir, he looked up a lady, and a gentleman, in his bed-chamber here, in the way of a joke only; was call'd down about some business; forgot it by the time he came to the foot of the stairs, went our with the key in his pocket, and it was six o'clock before we could set the pounded couple at liberty.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: His ideas are so confused sometimes, sir, that I have known him write a letter to one person, direct it to another, and sent it to a third, who could not devise who it came from; because, he had forgot to put his name to the bottom on't.

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: A beggar takes off his hat to him in the See relevant passage from Rowe, LaBruyere (1713): beggar at church door street, in hopes of recieving an alms; Mr. Shatterbrain makes him a low bow, tells him, he's his most obedient humble servant, and walks on.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: But the best thing I have heard of him a good while, was, what he did lately at a gentleman's See relevant passage from Rowe, LaBruyere (1713): thinking he is in his own house, plays host house in the city; where taking his leave with an intention to go away; in one of his absent fits, he mounted up three pair of stars into the garret; the maids that by chance were ironing there, wonder'd what the plague kept such a stamping about the rooms, when one of them taking a candle to see what it was, found my poor paster; who, in the utmost confusion, told her, he fancy'd he had made some mistake, and begg'd to know if that was not the way to the street door.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Well, I don't know; but, if his present behavior proceeds from his forgetfulness, it is the most extrodinary instance of the kind that ever was heard of; and, how shall I proceed in this case; my daughter is at home ready dressed; the lawyer will be there presently with the writings; I have taken out a licence; appointed the clergyman to come and marry the; how shall I put it off after this, without making us all ridiculous?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: 'Tis very true, sir, I am sure I have been at my wits end about it all day.

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: Suppose, Mr. Frank, you were to go and look for your master again; what if you gave a peep into the Bedford coffee-house?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Shall I, sir?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: If you think you will find him there.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: It can be no harm to try, sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Very well, I'll wait for you; go, and make what haste you can.

div.note: The 1768 play indicates here again that this is Scene III, most likely becuase Frank has left the scene. That designation ahs been removed in favor of the stage direction.
div.stage: Doctor Gruel, Landlady.

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: I hope he may find him.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: So do I with all my heart; for, on many acounts, I would not wish to have my daughter's marriage delay'd; her own indiscretion, Madam, has occasioned me to treat her with a severity of late, very irksome both to herself and me.

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: That's a pity, sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: In truth and so it is: few father have taken greater care in the education of a child, nor has that care been wholly unprofitable; for I think I may say without vanity, that there is not a young woman in England, of her age and station, more completely accomplished than my Flavia.

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: And yet she has no more pride, I warrant, than a boarding-school girl, in the first row of her sampler.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: That's her fault, madam&emdash;a proper pride is woman's virtue&emdash;I should be sorry to see my daughter give herself airs, but at the same time I would have her know her proper value; I would not have her throw herself away.

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: No, to be sure, sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: And yet, had I not interposed my parental authority, such was her purpose, Madam; if I may call it throwing herself away, to marry a young fellow not worth a groat.

div.head: Scene IV
div.stage: Doctor Gruel, Landlady, Frank out of breath.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: My master's coming, Sir.

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: As I'm a Christian, I'm glad on't.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Where did you meet him?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: I met him, Sir&emdash;O Lord&emdash;I met him at the end of the street, Sir&emdash;where he has been Heaven knows, but such a figure&emdash;So, Sir, I told him I had been in search after him all day, and how you were waiting here&emdash;but if I had snapped a pistol at his breast, it could not have put him in greater consternation&emdash;he took to his heels, directly, like a madman; and I have almost run myself breathles in order to get home before him, and bring the tidings to your worship.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Why, this is as it should be, Madam.

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: Ay, ay, Sir, all's right again&emdash;but I hear Mr. Shatterbrain coming up, so I'll take my leave.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: I wish you a good evening; we shall hear now what this whimsical gentleman will have to say for himself

div.head: Scene V
div.stage: Doctor Gruel, Frank, Shatterbrain.

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Come, my things, do dress quickly&emdash;my things to dress.&emdash; Doctor Gruel you most obedient humble servant&emdash;I beg ten thousand pardons, but I'll be ready to wait on you immediately&emdash;Frank, why don't you make haste?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: I am making all the haste I can, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Time enough, time enough.

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: I hope, Sir, your mother's very well?

div.note: See relevant passage from Rowe, LaBruyere (1713): asking after widow's husband

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: My mother! Sir?

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Yes, Sir, I hope she is&emdash;a&emdash;

sp.speaker: Doctor
Shatter
sp.p: For your daughter! Upon my word, and so I do&emdash;bless my soul, what was I thinking of. Did I say your mother? No, no; your daughter to be sure. How does Miss Gruel, Sir?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Very well, and at your service heartily&emdash; if you recollect we agreed to comsummate our affairs this evening. Accordingly I have disposed every thing for that purpose; and having a patient to visit in your neighborhood here, called in my return home to take you along with me&emdash;guess then how I was surprised when the people told me you had gone our early, and nobody knew whither.

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Really, sir, I am quite ashamed&emdash;but up on my word it went out if my head.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Why, so your servant said he was sure it had,; and I am very well pleased to find he was not mistaken&emdash;for in truth I was apprehensive that it proceeded from a worse cause, and some ill accident detain'd you&emdash;but where the duce have you been with your shoes and stockings?

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Frank, what are you doing? My shoes and stockings, sir? Why they are in a very beastly See relevant passage from Rowe, LaBruyere (1713): leaving house in state of undress pickle, that's the truth on't&emdash;and now I look at them again, upon my soul I am amazed how I could contrive to make them so&emdash;though the roads were confounded deep; and if they had been a fathom, it would have been just the same&emdash;for I never pick my steps, but wade through the middle of every thing&emdash;I had like to have been run over once or twice.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Then you walked in to the country?

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Faith, sir, I had no thoughts of it when I left home&emdash;but, I don't know how it was, the beauty of the weather had enticed me as far as Putney, before I percieved that I was in t'other side the river; where, meeting with a party of friends going to dine at Richmond, I made a fifth in their vehicle&emdash;by the way I was obliged to get one of the See relevant passage from Rowe, LaBruyere (1713): getting in wrong carriage ladies to pay my reckoning&emdash;for when I came to put my hand in my pocket&emdash;the duce a farthing had I about me.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: No, that I will answer for&emdash;here is your purse, Sir, you left it on the hall table, last night, when you were discharging the chairman&emdash;and 'twas very well I went down as I did, or ten to one but somebody might have whipped it away.

div.note: See relevant passage from Rowe, LaBruyere (1713): robbed by footman

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Which would have been a loss to me, I see&emdash;tho' I don't know how much was in it.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: But did not you talk of dressing? If you have any such intention, you had better do it speedily, and as you will be some little time about it, I will make use of the oppertunity to dispatch a few visits, which I must necessarily make this afternoon&emdash;you will come as soon as you are ready&emdash; and believe me, when I assure you, I long to see you one of my family.

div.head: Scene VI
div.stage: Shatterbrain, Frank.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: By god, Sir, we had like to have been all to pieces here&emdash;I believe the Doctor thought you had given him the slip, and that you would not take the goods oﬀ his hands, after you had bar- gained for them.

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Very well he might think so&emdash;and you Mr. Dunderpate, when you knew how my aﬀairs were circumstanced, why did not you put me in mind?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Because, Sir, I thought&emdash;

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Because you always think wrong, Sir&emdash; Was there any one to enquire for me here to day?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Yes, Sir, Mr. Welldon was here five or six times.

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Welldon!

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: I believe he is but just come to town, Sir, for he had his boots on&emdash;he said he'd call again.

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: If he should, let him know I shall be glad to see him at Doctor Gruel's, which will be my place of reﬁdence henceforward. (After picking his teeth, in a negligent manner, while Frank seems to put his things in order.)Well! upon my soul, Mrs. Junket is a very agreeable woman, and so is her friend, Miss Frolick. I have not spend a day more pleasantly a great while&emdash;

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Was your honour with those ladies to day then? I saw them go by in a coach and four, with Captain Slang, and Mr. Coxcomb&emdash;But let me look at you a little, Sir&emdash;iſ I may be so bold as to ask the question, pray do you intend to salute this young lady, this evening?

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: What would the puppy be at?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Because, Sir, if your mind is bent that way&emdash;I would beg leave to salute you ﬁrst with my razor&emdash;odds bobs, if you should attempt to go near her with that bristly beard!&emdash;

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Give me my cap.

sp.speaker: Frank
Shatter
sp.p: Apropos, Frank, cou'd you ever learn where I lost my boot, the last day I was out a riding?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Lord, Sir, how should I learn, I never heard of such a thing in my life!

sp.speaker: Shatter
Frank
sp.p: (aside)It's well your legs are not loose, we should soon have you reduced to your stumps

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Whu, Whu.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Consider what I'm doing, Sir! If you Remainder of line illegible; it is mose likely Frank is admonishing Shatter to remain still or he will accidentally cut him.

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Cut me! 'Sdeath that razor is ﬁt to cut nothing but deal-boards; 'tis a perfect saw: change it directly.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: I will, Sir, I will.

div.head: Scene VII
div.stage: Shatterbrain, Frank, Welldon.

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: My dear Welldon, ten thousand welcomes.
sp.stage: (Shatterbrain, forgetting the condition he is in, rises with the cloth about him, and runs and salutes Welldon on both sides of the face)
sp.p: My fellow tells me you have designed me this favour two or three times to day.

sp.speaker: Well
sp.p: I have called here more than once, I believe.

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Because you had any particular commands for me, or only en passant?

sp.speaker: Well
sp.p: Oh, no very particular commands&emdash;But I seem to have broke in upon you abruptly.

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: My friends can never do so, sir, though I must own I could wish you had timed your visit a little better, for such is the malignity of my stars, that I cannot at present stay to enjoy the benefit of it. I must leave you, my boy, and I will give you half an hour to guess the occasion, which forces me to do a thing, otherwise so repugnant to my inclinations.

sp.speaker: Well
sp.p: I am the worst diviner in the world; I can not even draw consequences.

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Then, without farther circumlocution, sir, I am going to be married.

sp.speaker: Well
sp.p: Married!

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: (Taking out his snuff box.) The Devil take me but I am.

sp.speaker: Well
sp.p: Then my intelligence is just, and all my fears are true.

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Do you ever take snuff?

sp.speaker: Well
sp.p: Confusion!

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Hey you, Sir Frank, what have you done to my snuff, blockhead? 'Tis wet, and smells of soap.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Wet and smells of soap, sir! Well it may, is not your face all over lather? Sure I had but just began to shave you.

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Oh, follow me into the next room, and make an end of it. You'll excuse my taking this liberty.

div.head: Scene VIII
div.stage: Welldon and afterwards Frank.

sp.speaker: Welldon
sp.p: Pray make no apologies&emdash;Unkind Flavia&emdash;but why do I upbraid her with unkindess, who may possibly be in equal distress with myself?&emdash;If I can't prevent the match, it were better almost that I had got no intelligence of it&emdash;Yet he seems to be ignorant that I am his rival, and I will ﬂatter myself that my good genius has brought me here thus critically, to sound the whole truth of the aﬀair; and by some unforeseen means or other, make me instrumental to the advancement of my own happiness.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Mr. Welldon! what's the matter.

sp.speaker: Well
sp.p: But I deserve it all&emdash;Oh Frank, how shall I tell you!

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Out with it.

sp.speaker: Well
sp.p: Your master is going to be married to the only woman upon earth that can make me happy.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: (Looking very gravely in his face)What a strange and unaccountable thing is love&emdash;which, like an inundation, turns every thing that stands in its way topsy turvy&emdash;Misleads the judgment&emdash;blinds the understanding&emdash;and, from reasonable creatures, leaves us little better than whimpering idiots&emdash;The strongest it overpowers&emdash;the most wary it circumvents&emdash;it smarts the wise man&emdash;and it tickles the fool.

sp.speaker: Well
sp.p: What nonsense is this!&emdash;Do you laugh at me?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: 'Fore Cupid not I, Sir&emdash;But how, in the name of common sense, can you imagine that I should be able to assist you?

sp.speaker: Well
sp.p: Well, I don't know&emdash;I'm almost mad.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: So one would think&emdash;But if this young lady makes such tearing work in your heart, 'tis seven or eight days since her father oﬀered her to my master&emdash;what have you been doing all this time?

sp.speaker: Well
sp.p: Nothing&emdash;In daily expectation of receiving a letter from her, I never dreamt of any thing of this kind, till a friend writ me word he heard such a report; upon which, I immediately took horse, and judging that all access would be denied me at Doctor Gruel's, came here the moment I got my foot out of the stirrup.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: And to what purpose?&emdash;You did not suppose that my master would give her up to you?

sp.speaker: Well
sp.p: I supposed she should; nay, and I swear he shall give her up to me&emdash;

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Fair and softly, good Sir&emdash;What would you say now if I should tell you, that this match is made up with the young lady's own consent; and that she likes Mr. Shatterbrain better than you?

sp.speaker: Well
sp.p: Impossible!&emdash;If there be any such thing as faith or constancy, in woman. But I'll know the truth of that presently&emdash;I'll go to her father's house; by some means or other get admittance; and, if I ﬁnd her false&emdash;

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: You'll go hang yourself in your garters; a very heroic revenge truly&emdash;Well I shall not mention a word to my master of what you have told me&emdash; but mum.

div.head: Scene IX
div.stage: Welldon, Frank, Shatterbrain.

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Frank, where is my sword? I have been looking for it all over the next room, and can't find it.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Your sword, sir! Your sword (looking about for it.) why it hung in the next chamber, behind the door.

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Oh, it hung, it hung&emdash; you are the most careless fellow.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Why I'm very sure, sir, I did not&emdash;(look- ing about) Lord, is not that it in your hand, sir ?

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Ha! Upon my soul it is.

sp.speaker: Well
sp.p: Well, Mr. Shatterbrain, I'll take my leave.

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Why in such a hurry?

sp.speaker: Well
sp.p: I have some particular business&emdash;and shall but detain you.

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Nay if you have business&emdash;But, I hope, I shall have the pleasure of seeing you when I can enjoy your company longer, and entertain you better.

sp.speaker: Well
sp.p: You may depend upon it&emdash;the pleasure will be to myself.

div.head: Scene X
div.stage: Frank, Shatterbrain.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Come, for Heaven's sake, Sir, get yourself away; the Doctor will imagine you have forgot again.

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Is there a chair at the door?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: There's always half a score standing at the next coffee-house.

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Well, the boy below will get me one. Do you take care of the things in the next room: and, d'ye hear&emdash;what was I going to say?&emdash;Bring my night-gown and slippers to Doctor Gruel's precisely at ten.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: I'll take care, Sir.

div.stage: Frank goes out, and Shatterbrain takes his hat from the table as if going out too, but suddenly stops at the door.

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Frank, Frank.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: (Within)Here, Sir, coming, Sir

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Frank, why don't you make haste, Frank?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: (Entering)What do you want, Sir?

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Nothing.Exit with his hat over his night cap.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: would think the absent Devil had possessed me, as There appears to be a missing line from the previous page here. well as him&emdash;Ho, sir!

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: (Returning)What ails the fellow? What do you bawl so for?

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Your wig, Sir.

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Well, Sir, and could not you say so, without making a noise as if the house was on ﬁre? Give it me.

div.head: Scene XI
div.stage: Frank, Landlady.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Thanks to Providence, he's gone at last.

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: At last, indeed!

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Hey-day! Who have we here?

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: Lord be merciful to me, I'm sure no such visitors come to me. (Knocking again.)Again&emdash; why, Sally, Susan! Are you all deaf? One had need keep a porter at this rate.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: By the impudence of this rap now, it should be either a person of quality or a dun. Who is it?

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: (Having gone to the door.) I can't tell; there's a whole coach full enquiring for your master.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: My master!

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: See if they are not coming out!

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Let me look&emdash;the people he dined with at Richmond, by the mackins.

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: What do they want here, I wonder!

div.head: Scene XII
div.stage: Mrs. Junket, Miss Frolick, Slang, Coxcomb, the Company enter laughing.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jun
sp.p: But where's Shatterbrain?&emdash;I want him to pay me my two and twenty shillings: Shatterbrain, you poor brute, where are you?

sp.speaker: Miss Frolick
sp.p: Mr. Shatterbrain

sp.speaker: Cox
sp.p: Mr Shatterbrian.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jun
sp.p: Suppose, Sir, you were to imform your master that we are here.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: My master is not at home, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jun
sp.p: Not at home!

sp.speaker: Slang
sp.p: What will you do now?

sp.speaker: Miss Frolick
sp.p: Why he left us as soon as he eat his dinner, with an intent of coming home directly. If he is no better a walker, he might as well have stay'd for the coach.

sp.speaker: Cox
sp.p: And yet I thought he set out a good round pace too.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jun
sp.p: I take my death this is very pretty; I wonder we did not pass him on the road!&emdash;But he is such a strange creature! I'll be hang'd if he has not gone some round-about way.&emdash;I wish now we had not been in such a hurry to leave Richmond, for ten to one whether he'll be in this half hour.

sp.speaker: Miss Frolick
sp.p: And all this time we shall have nothing to do.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jun
sp.p: Here's four of us ; what if we sat down to a game at cards? 'twill serve to amuse us a little, and I want to win some money&emdash;Your master has invited us to supper, Sir, so since he is not come in yet, if you'll set the card-table, and get a couple of packs of cards, we'll play a game or two till he does&emdash; Heigh ho!

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Madam!&emdash;Invited them to supper!

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: Oh crimine!

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: My master has been at home, Madam, and is gone out again for the remainder of the night.

sp.speaker: Slang
sp.p: A fair hum, by the Lord.

sp.speaker: Cox
sp.p: Is this not high?

sp.speaker: Miss Frolick
sp.p: I am at a loss what to make on't.&emdash;You know where he is gone, I presume?

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: Yes, Madam, he's gone to be married.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jun
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Miss Frolick
sp.p: This is better and better.

sp.speaker: Cox
sp.p: 'Tis something funny, faith.

sp.speaker: Slang
sp.p: I wish, however, he had omitted the jest of Remainder of page missing. The words "ommitted the jest of" are half cut off.

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: Nay, Sir, don't be angry with him, I'll be sworn he did not think of it then&emdash;The Doctor came for him himself&emdash;He has but just leſt the house.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jun
sp.p: Hist&emdash;What Doctor came here for him?

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: Dr. Gruel Madam&emdash;

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jun
sp.p: Whose daughter he is gone to be married to, depend upon't. I heard something of this before&emdash;Frolick, do you remember a letter I read you, somse time ago concerning a certain relation of mine and Flavia Gruel? Perhaps one of you may know him, Billy Welldon.

sp.speaker: Slang
sp.p: Yes, I have seen him about the Garden.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jun
Miss Frolick
sp.p: Oh, and old huncks! and loves money by all accounts.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jun
sp.p: By the way, I could put you in a method of playing a charming trick&emdash;What if we were to follow Shatterbrain to Doctor Gruel's?

sp.speaker: Miss Frolick
sp.p: An admirable project.

sp.speaker: Cox
sp.p: But of your own proposing, ladies, remember that.

sp.speaker: Slang
sp.p: Damn me, I'll do anything.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jun
sp.p: Give me your hand, then&emdash;This will be serving Shatterbrain right for the manner he has treated us. Besides, I owe the Doctor a grudge on my cousin's account, and I know it will fret his guts to fiddle-strings. Frolick, what do you think of this?

sp.speaker: Miss Frolick
sp.p: It diverts me of all things.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jun
sp.p: She and I are very intimate there&emdash; But what do we stay for?&emdash;follow your leader.

sp.speaker: Cox
sp.p: Madam will you do me the honor of your little finger?

sp.speaker: Miss Frolick

div.head: Scene XIII
div.stage: Frank and Landlady.

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Oh, the devil break your neck&emdash;And have not you done a very pretty spot of work here? I shall be afraid to see my master's face now; to be sure he'll lay all the blame of this upon me.

sp.speaker: Land
sp.p: No, no; if there be any words about it, I'll take the fault upon myself. Will you step into the parlour, and drink a dish of tea? And afterwards we'll have a game at Pam Loo. There's cousin Spriggins, and Mrs. Allum the baker's wife, at next door. You know I won four-pence half penny from you last night, and I'll give you your revenge&emdash;

sp.speaker: Frank
sp.p: Psha, rot my revenge&emdash;I shall be played the mischief with, and all because you could not keep your tongue within your teeth.

div.head: Scene I
div.stage: Changes to an antichamber in Dr. Gruel's house.
Welldon, Robin

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Pray now, sir, walk softly; can't you tread upon your tip-toes as I do?

sp.speaker: Welldon
sp.p: My honest little lad, I tread as softly as ever I can.

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Did you scrape your shoes before you came up?

sp.speaker: Welldon
sp.p: I did.

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: If the old codger should come now!&emdash;we expects him every minute&emdash;'Ecod I would not for sixpence, so I would not&emdash;If he did, and knew I let you in, he'd lick me to pieces.

sp.speaker: Welldon
sp.p: Never fear&emdash;But you have done nothing, after all, without you procure me a fight of Miss Flavia.

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: What!

sp.speaker: Welldon
sp.p: Without you procure me a sight of Miss Flavia, I say, you might as well have left me stand- ing in the street still.

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Oh, faith, I can't.

sp.speaker: Welldon
sp.p: Try.

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: I can't, as I hope to be saved.

sp.speaker: Welldon
sp.p: What did you think I wanted to come into the house for then?

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Nay, I did not know; I thought you only wanted to come in.

sp.speaker: Welldon
sp.p: Psha!

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Why, 'tis true; you did not say nothing about wanting to see Miss Flavia. Besides, she has company with her, and I could tell you a secret, so I could, if you'd swear you would not mention it.

sp.speaker: Welldon
sp.p: I won't, upon honour.

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: She's to be married tonight, then; mas- ter's gone for her husband and the parson.

sp.speaker: Welldon
sp.p: I'll tell you what, Robin, if you'll con- trive to let Miss Flavia know, that I am here, and would be glad to speak with her, I'll give you this half-crown.

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: No, but you won't.

sp.speaker: Welldon
sp.p: Take it, and put it in your pocket.

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Give me your hand&emdash;odds bobs, you're a rare fellow. Stay here, I am just going to carry in the tea; I'll give her a sly pinch, and bring her out to you directly.

div.head: Scene II
div.stage: Weldon, then Robin, who runs across the stage, and Flavia, who follows him.

sp.speaker: Welldon
sp.p: Thus far I have succeeded then, to the utmost bounds of my wishes; and, if I can but go on with equal success&emdash;

sp.speaker: Flavia
sp.p: Somebody wants me! Oh heavens! Mr. Weldon!

sp.speaker: Welldon
sp.p: You wonder to see me&emdash; Perhaps you are dislpeased.

sp.speaker: Falvia
sp.p: Not so; and yet, every thing consider'd, I don't know whether I have not reason&emdash;What brought you to town, and how did you gain admittance here?

sp.speaker: Welldon
sp.p: I have no time to answer such superfluous questions; rather let me ask you why I have never received a line from you since you left the country?

sp.speaker: Flavia
sp.p: To what end could my writing to you have served?

sp.speaker: Welldon
sp.p: Oh! Flavia, I little thought, when we parted last, that, the next time we met, I should find you (so far from being mine) that you would be on the very point of becoming another's.

sp.speaker: Flavia
sp.p: Can you blame me for my obedience to my father?

sp.speaker: Welldon
sp.p: I am answer'd. I was told, before I came here, indeed, that you were going to be disposed of with your own consent. I must confess I was weak enough not to discredit it; but that error of my judgment being fully rectified, I shall take my leave, and trouble you no farther.

sp.speaker: Flavia
sp.p: Stay&emdash;'tis true I have given my consent to a match which (as you are informed, I suppose) within these few hours is to be concluded; but if you imagine I gave that consent in compliance with my own inclinations&emdash;

sp.speaker: Welldon
sp.p: Can i imagine otherwise?

sp.speaker: Flavia
sp.p: To do me justice you must&emdash;

div.head: Scene III
div.stage: Weldon, Flavia, Robin

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Miss! Miss! here's your papa.

sp.speaker: Flavia
sp.p: My father!

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Come with me, Sir, and I'll put you into the back-garret.

sp.speaker: Flavia
sp.p: Dear Weldon, there's my dressing-room; the boy will show you a closet in it, where you may hide till we go into the next room, and then steal down unperceived.

sp.speaker: Welldon
sp.p: How can you make me such a cruel proposal?

sp.speaker: Flavia
sp.p: Where's the cruelty of it?

sp.speaker: Welldon
sp.p: What! do you think I'll go tamely away and leave Shatterbrain to triumph? By Heaven I'll not&emdash;I'll stay and confront your father.

sp.speaker: Flavia
sp.p: Pray pity me; I'm ready to die with apprehension.

sp.speaker: Welldon
sp.p: No, no, I'll stay I'm determined.

sp.speaker: Flavia
sp.p: Avoid him but for this moment, and make your own conditions.

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: By the lord Harry I head=r him.

sp.speaker: Welldon
sp.p: Well upon one proviso, dispose of me as you please.

sp.speaker: Flavia
sp.p: Name it.

sp.speaker: Welldon
Flavia
sp.p: I swear I never will, let what will be the consequence.

sp.speaker: Welldon
sp.p: Enough&emdash;where shall I go?

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Follow me, Sir, and I'll show you.

div.head: Scene IV
div.stage: Doctor Gruel, Flavia, and thenRobin.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Flavia, child, I hear you have got company within ; who are they?

sp.speaker: Flavia
sp.p: Mrs. Junket and Miss Frolick, Sir, with two gentlemen I never saw before.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Impertinence! What brought them here? And was it not my positive commands&emdash;

sp.speaker: Flavia
sp.p: They were told at the door, Sir, that we were not at home; but it seems they would take no denial.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Psha! What have you been doing in your young lady's dressing-room, sirrah?

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: What shall I say, Miss?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: The oaf stares as it he had seen a ghost.

sp.speaker: Flavia
sp.p: I'm frightened out of my wits.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Why does he not anser me?

sp.speaker: Flavia
sp.p: Robin, why don't you answer my papa? What have you been doing in my dressing room?

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Sure, Miss, you knwo very well what I have been doing there.

sp.speaker: Flavia
sp.p: If he discovers me, I am undone.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Is the rascal playing tricks? Speak,

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Pussy, pussy, pussy, pussy.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: What does the rascal mean by pussy, pussy?

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Why, Sir, I was looking for the&emdash;

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Get out of my sight,&emdash;How long has Mr. Shatterbrain been come?

sp.speaker: Flavia
sp.p: I have heard nothing of him since, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Grant me patience! Go desire one of the men to run to Mr. Shatterbrain's lodgings, and tell him we wait for him.

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

stage.hi: Doctor Gruel, Flavia, Mrs. Junket, Miss Frolick, Slang, Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jun.
sp.p: Oh, Doctor Gruel! I'm vastly glad you are come; I have been longing for you here, at such a rate&emdash;give me leave to present a couple of friends of mine to you&emdash;this is Captain Slang.

sp.speaker: Slang
sp.p: I hope you're pretty well, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jun.
sp.p: This is Mr. Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: Sir, your most devoted.

sp.speaker: Miss Frolick
sp.p: Doctor Gruel, how do you do?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: At your service, Madam&emdash;well, the familiar impudence of some people is astonishing!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jun.
sp.p: I believe you did not expect to find us all here, did you?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: I cannot say, Madam, I expected to meet quite so much good company.

sp.speaker: Miss Frolick
sp.p: Nay, we thought we should surprise you&emdash;but one of the drolest accidents has happen'd to us this afternoon.

sp.speaker: Slang
sp.p: She's in earnest, Sir&emdash;we have had a hellish droll adventure, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Mes. Jun.
sp.p: Something so whimsical and out of way, you'll die with laughing when you hear it.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Then I don't desire to hear it at all, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jun.
sp.p: Shatterbrain dined with us today in teh country.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Did he so&emdash;then, I suppose, it is to his invintation, I am indebted for the honour of this visit.

sp.speaker: Miss Frolick
sp.p: It is, and not owing to his invitation.

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: Riddle me, riddle me ree.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: I don't understand you, Madam.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jun.
sp.p: No!&emdash;Listen then, and you shall hear, how that monster of rudeness has served us&emdash;but here he cormes to answer for himself.

div.head: Scene V
div.note: Although this is labeld as scene five, it is actually scene six by count. The scene numbering remains confused untiil scene eight.
div.stage: Doctor Gruel, Slang, Coxcomb, Mrs. Junket, Miss Frolick, Flavia, and Shatterbrain who pops in, and runs back again.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Mr. Shatterbrain, Mr. Shatterbrain, do we frighten you?

sp.speaker: Shatter.
sp.p: Cry you mercy&emdash;seeing so much company, I thought I had made a mistake again.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Again!

sp.speaker: Shatter.
Mrs. Jun.
sp.p: he takes no more notice of us, than if we were not in the room.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: To whom must I make your excuses, and what about?

sp.speaker: Shatter.
sp.p: Are you acquainted with the family at next door?

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: They and I have lived upon the same steps these twenty years.

sp.speaker: Shatter.
sp.p: I wish, with all my soul, you had liv'd twenty leagues asunder&emdash; the damned fellows that brought me from my lodgings, not knowing your house, when they set me down, instead of knocking servant came (who I afterwards found thought me an apothecary) I made no more ado, but desired them to open the chair and walk'd in without any farther ceramony [sic], taking it for granted I was here.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: You did not!

sp.speaker: Shatter
Doctor
sp.p: Oh Lord! that was poor Mrs. Feebles; she has been bed rid a good while.

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Pox on her&emdash;I had not got into the room two yards, before I stumbled over a stool; which roused the old Beldam, and she cryed out in a voice, between hoarse and squeeking&emdash;Who's there? to which I made no reply, for I began to suspect that I had committed some blunder. When putting her head out of the curtains, and perceiving, by the light of the fire, a person she did not know, she set up her pipes, and squalled to such a pitch, that the whole house was about us in an instant.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: How did you get clear of them?

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Why, after looking pretty much like a fool, as you may guess; I ask'd if that was not your house? To which being answered in the negative, I offer'd a thousand apologies; told them the plain truth; and one of the footmen luckily happening to know me, I march'd of with flying colours, a whole skin, and a tolerable good reputation.

sp.speaker: Slang
sp.p: When if they had been as well acquainted with you as I am, they would have suspected that you came with a villainous design against the old woman, and us'd you accordingly&emdash;Come, come, Mr. Shatterbrain, gentlemen don't steal into Ladies bed-chambers for nothing.

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: What, my fellow traveller! Mrs. Junket, Miss Frolick, Mr. Coxcomb!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jun.
sp.p: Oh! You have found us out at last!

sp.speaker: Miss. Frolick
sp.p: You are a very pretty gentleman, truly!

sp.speaker: Cox.
sp.p: I hope you got safe to town, Sir?

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Very safe; but do you know, that I am, beginning to recollect, that I have been devilish rude to you?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Jun.
sp.p: You are, are you?

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Did not you ask me to sup with you somewhere to-night?

sp.speaker: Slang
sp.p: No, by the Lord, but you asked us.

sp.speaker: Shatter
sp.p: Did I&emdash;Faith, I believe it was so; well, I beg your pardons; but you must forgive me this time, for you see I lay under an engagement, which I could not posiibly postpone.

sp.speaker: Doctor
sp.p: Ladies and gentlemen, Mr. Shatterbrain, my daughter and I have some private business to transact; I expect my lawyer here every minute; and if you will step into the drawing-room, we'll do ourselves the pleasure to attend you there presently.

sp.speaker: Slang
sp.p: Ay, ay, don't let us interrupt business.

sp.speaker: Miss. Frolick
sp.p: No Ceremony, I beseech you.

sp.speaker: Cox
sp.p: Ladies, you'll shew us the way.

sp.speaker: Miss Jun.
sp.p: Good bye, Crazy.

div.stage: slapping Shatterbrain on the back as she goes out

div.head: Scene VIII
div.note: The scene numbers here skip from scene five to scene eight with no noticable break in the print text.
div.stage: Doctor Gruel, seeing the company to the Door, Flavis, Shattterbrain, and Robin with a Letter.

sp.speaker: Robin
sp.p: Here's a letter, Sir, the gentleman's servant is below.

sp.speaker: Shatter.
sp.p: A letter! give it me (taking the letter without looking at the superscription, he opens and reads it to himself) bless my soul Doctor Gruel, here's a very odd thing; egad, I don't know well what to make of it, but I believe I must go from you for a little while, for it seems to be on an affair of life and death.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Indeed, I am sorry to hear this; pray explain, what is the matter?

sp.speaker: Shatter.
sp.p: Why, faith, that is whatl would be glad to know myself, but, as I told you before, I don't very well understand&emdash;'Tis true, I am acquainted in my Lord's family, but not very intimate, and they desire me here to come in all haste, for they are afraid he's in his laſt moments; What the devil can they want with me? I can be of no service to him.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Pr'ythee ! Pr'thee, let me look at it? Why, this letter's to me, sirrah, how came you&emdash;

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Please your worship, I said it was for you, but the gentleman took it out of my hand. (Here Flaviaflurting her fan, Shatterbrainrakes ir from her, in an absent fit, and begins to fiddle with it.)

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: This is an exceeding unlucky affair? Is my Lord's servant below?

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Why id dyou say I was at home&emdash;tell him&emdash;

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: He says, if you don't come directly, my Lord will be dead.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Nay, then I must go&emdash;Well, my dear, Shatterbrain you'll entertain my daughter till I come back. Robin, set wine and glasses upon the table; it is but at the end of the street, and I shall be back in twenty minutes at farthest.

sp.speaker: Shatter.
sp.p: Pray offer no excuses.&emdash;but wont you take this along with you (offering him the fan)

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: It is my daughter's I believe.

sp.speaker: Shatter.
sp.p: I beg ten thousand pardons&emdash;I hope Miss, I have not done it any mischief (giving it to her torn to pieces)

div.head: Scene VIII
div.stage: Shatterbrian, Flavia, Robin, who sets wine upon the table, and afterwards Welldon.

sp.speaker: Shatter.
sp.p: Madam, won't you chuse to be seated&emdash;a chair (Robin places an armed chair which Shatterbrain sits down in himself: musing and laying one leg carelesslv over the other, without taking any notice of Flavia. He pulls out his snuff-box spilling his snuff; takes a letter for his pocket handkerchief; then garters his stockings, etc.)

sp.speaker: Flavia.
sp.p: I am very oddly circumstanc'd here, however, I'll keep my word with Welldon, that I'm determin'd: but how to do it is the thing&emdash;Mrs. Junket is a pure body in those cases, I'll e'en go and advise with her.

sp.speaker: Shatter.
sp.p: (Not perceiving that Flavia has stolen off)I'll assure you, Madam, it is with infinite satisfaction, that I conclude this alliance with Doctor Gruel's family; and though I have not had an opportunity of paying my court to you, as much as you might expect, I am not less warm in my wishes, nor sincere in my attachment; nor have I the least doubt of our being as happy when married, as if my addresses had been longer: for a man, Madam, may make a very affectionate husband, without having been a very violent lover: it indeed often happens, that the length of preliminaries weakens the vigour of the contract, and so&emdash; (turning about by degrees and looking all round, theroom) Miss&emdash; MissFlavia; Hey dey, gone, left me (taþping at the door where Welldon is) where are you?

sp.speaker: Welldon.
sp.p: Here, here, (Welldon opens the door and Shatterbrain takes him by the hand without looking at him.)

sp.speaker: Shatter.
sp.p: You were gone before I miss'd you.

sp.speaker: Welldon
sp.p: Shatterbrain, theh devil (struggling to get loose)

sp.speaker: Shatter.
sp.p: Nay, I hold you now, and you shan't escape. Come sit down here, I must have a little serious conversation with you (seats him in the chair, and pulling another for himsef perceives his mistake) Welldon!

sp.speaker: Welldon.
sp.p: Pague on it.

sp.speaker: Shatter.
sp.p: Sure, I did not ask you to supper too.

sp.speaker: Welldon.
sp.p: Does he banter me.

stage.hi: Shatterbrain, Welldon, Mrs. Junket, Miss Frolick, Flavia.

sp.speaker: Flavia.
sp.p: Defend me! What do I see?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: Nevermind; (to Miss Frolick) do you draw off Shatterbrain.

sp.speaker: Miss. Frolick.
sp.p: I will if I can. Mr.Shatterbrain, you have had no tea this evening; if you will step into the next room, I will give you a cup.

sp.speaker: Shatter.
sp.p: I shall be proud to receive any thing from your fair hands, Madam&emdash; Welldon I'm glad to see you. (Shatterbrain goes out with Miss Frolick, leaving Welldon, Flavia, and Mrs. Junket on the Stage.

sp.speaker: Flavia.
sp.p: How came this about, why did not you stay were you were?

sp.speaker: Welldon.
sp.p: "Sdeath, I'm in amaze, I thought you called me.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: Hold your confounded tongues; is it not time enough for you to squabble when you are man and wife?

sp.speaker: Flavia.
sp.p: Heaven knows when that will be.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: If you follow m y directions, I will put you in a method of bringing it about immediately.

sp.speaker: Welldon.
sp.p: My dear creature.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: Hands off, none of your raptures, I beseech you; Is not the parson who is to marry you and Shatterbrain now in the house?

sp.speaker: Flavia.
sp.p: Yes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: Who is he?

sp.speaker: Flavia.
sp.p: Supple, my Lord Courtland's chaplin.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: I think you said within that he and Shatterbrain were utter strangers.

sp.speaker: Flavia.
sp.p: I hear him ask my father yesterday what sort of a man Shatterbrain was.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: Does Supple, my Lord Courtland's chaplain know any thing of you?

sp.speaker: Welldon.
sp.p: He never saw me in his life, I'm positive.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: Then the business is done, if you will only take my advice, and have a little confidence. (A loud laugh without) Bless me!

sp.speaker: Welldon.
sp.p: Somebody is confoundedly tickled, but the jest moves this way.

stage.hi: Mrs. Junket, Welldon, Flavia, Slang, Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Coxcomb.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: What's the cause of this immoderate mirth?
I can't tell you&emdash;ha! ha! ha!&emdash;Oh zounds!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: I hope you can speak, Mr. Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Coxcomb.
sp.p: Not I, by Gad, Madam, nor do I believe I shall ever be able to speak again.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: Let us leave these people to their laughing. I tell you once more I have a scheme in my head that must be attended with success, only do as I bid you: Billy, take her by the hand, and follow me down stairs.

sp.speaker: Flavia.
sp.p: Nay, but have a little patience, it is a matter of consequence, and should be weigh'd.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: Weigh figs and raisins, it is an affair of consequence, and we have no time to weigh it. Billy, why don't you take her?

sp.speaker: Welldon.
sp.p: Nay, my dear Flavia, don't hesitate; 'tis true indeed, we have no time to lose; she is our friend, and will consult both our interests.

sp.speaker: Flavia.
sp.p: Well do with me what you please.

div.head: Scene XI
div.stage: Coxcomb, Shatterbrain, Miss Frolick and then Mrs. Junket.

sp.speaker: Coxcomb.
sp.p: Are you scalded?

sp.speaker: Shatterbrain.
sp.p: I believe I should if the tea had been hot enough; but, as it happens, I am come off pretty well, as to that particular. I am extremely sorry though that I was so unfortunate as to break the china bowl.

sp.speaker: Slang.
sp.p: What, in the name of vengeance, were you thinking of?

sp.speaker: Shatterbrain.
sp.p: Why, I imagin'd there had been a chair behind me.

sp.speaker: Miss. Frolick.
sp.p: And how could you, heedless creature, go to sit down without looking back.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: Frolick, come hither, I have something to say to you.

sp.speaker: Miss. Frolick.
sp.p: Where are Flavia and Welldon?spelled Weldon

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: Softly&emdash;Tacking together in the study.

sp.speaker: Miss. Frolick.
sp.p: Tacking together.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: Marrying&emdash;does that content you, I put them upon the project; the parson takes Welldon for Shatterbrain, and is now actually performing the ceremony.

sp.speaker: Frolick.
sp.p: I don't believe it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: Go and convince yourself.

sp.speaker: Miss. Frolick.
sp.p: I will, if it be only to catch you in a fib. In the past exchange, the text alternates between speaker designations Miss. Frolick, Frolick, Mrs. Junk, Mrs Jun, and Jun. I have regularized each to Mrs. Junket and Miss Frolick, repsectively.

stage.hi: Slang, Coxcomb, Shatterbrain spelled "Shateerbrain", Mrs. Junket.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: Shatterbrain, what was it you did just now, to make those creatures laugh so.

sp.speaker: Shatterbrain.
sp.p: A piece of my old giddiness; I had got a bowl of tea from Miss Frolick, and was going to sit down to drink it&emdash;but there being ne'er a chair behind me, souse I went to the bottom, and spilt the liquor over me, as you see.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: Thou wilt ever be a mad creature&emdash;Lord, I'm in a mighty joyous humour to-night. I wish we had fiddles here, I could dance from this, till six o'clock to-morrow morning. Tol lol lol. (taking Coxcomb by the hand, and dancing about) Coxcomb, we'll positively come to your lodgings one of these evenings, and you shall give us a dance, and a bit of supper. Tol de rol lol.

sp.speaker: Slang.
sp.p: (Taking a glass of wine) Mr. Shatterbrain here's to you.

sp.speaker: Shatterbrain.
sp.p: Pretty well, I thank you, Sir, I hope you are very well.

sp.speaker: Slang.
sp.p: Hey-day, cross purposes! Why zounds, man, I drink your health, I don't ask you how you do. You have been at Newmarket, I suppose.

sp.speaker: Shatterbrain.
sp.p: You have a better opinion of me than I deserve.

sp.speaker: Slang.
sp.p: The devil, never at Newmarket?

sp.speaker: Shatter.
sp.p: Never.

sp.speaker: Slang.
sp.p: There was excellent sport there last meeting, the Earl of Sweepstakes rid his own horse Fleabite, the best of three heats over the Beacon course for a thousand; I was within ten yards of him, when he came to the post. But it had like to have cost me dear, for I rid a damn'd skittish little jade, and striving to rein her back, she took head, and in spite of all I could do, run above a quarter of a mile with me&emdash;I was oblig'd to sling myself off at last, which I did&emdash;at the distance&emdash;Aye, by Gad, I am sure it was as far as from this to that there door.

sp.speaker: Shatterbrain.
sp.p: yYes, I believe it might be there, or therabouts.

sp.speaker: Slang.
sp.p: Why, you were not by?

sp.speaker: Shatterbrain.
sp.p: Sir!

sp.speaker: Slang.
sp.p: You were not by, I say?

sp.speaker: Shatterbrain.
sp.p: At what, Sir?

sp.speaker: Slang.
sp.p: Why, when my mare run away with me.

sp.speaker: Shatterbrain.
sp.p: Your mare!

sp.speaker: Slang.
sp.p: I'll be cursed if you know what I have been saying to you all this time.

sp.speaker: Shatterbrain.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir, not very well&emdash;but if you will be so good as to repeat it again, I'll take care to be more attentive.

div.head: Scene XIII
div.stage: Slang, Coxcomb, Shatterbrain, Mrs. Junket, Miss. Frolick, and then Doctor Gruel.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: Well, did I tell you the truth or not?

sp.speaker: Miss. Frolick.
sp.p: Yes, but a truth that exceeds the example of romance. Why, 'tis over; they are as much one as the church can make them: the Doctor is come home too. Welldon has been a lucky fellow.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: I would say so if he had got the girl's fortune. Where is he?

sp.speaker: Miss. Frolick.
sp.p: With Flavia, waiting their cue to appear&emdash;The Doctor will be up in a moment.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: Here he comes&emdash;Now for it.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Your servant, good folks&emdash;Mr. Shatterbrain, what is this I hear? I am told you have stole a match on us. Did you think I had deserted you, or that I would go back of my engagements, which occasioned you to be in such a hurry?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: Observe how Shatterbrain looks at him.

sp.speaker: Shatterbrain.
sp.p: Do you direct your discourse to me, Sir ?

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: I cannot say that ever I was much more astonished in my life. But, for Heaven's sake, my dear Shatterbrain, what unaccountable crotchet seiz'd you both?

sp.speaker: Shatterbrain.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, explain yourself.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Nay, there's no need of explanation&emdash;Only, I think, you might as well have stay'd till l came home, as have married my daughter in my absence.

sp.speaker: Coxcomb.
sp.p: What's this!&emdash;Are you married Shatterbrain?

sp.speaker: Shatterbrain.
sp.p: Not that I know of, upon my soul.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Why, sure, Sir!&emdash;I'll take my oath it is not three minutes since Mr. Supple told me he had just married you and my daughter at your own requests.

sp.speaker: Shatterbrain.
sp.p: Did Mr. Supple tell you so, Sir?

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: I suppose you did not desire him to keep it a secret.

sp.speaker: Shatterbrian.
sp.p: Not I, faith, Sir&emdash;for I never spoke a word to Mr. Supple since I was born.

sp.speaker: Miss. Frolick.
sp.p: Shatterbrain is in doubt whether he is married or not.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: I'll plague him,&emdash;But, Mr. Shatterbrain, you had better recollect yourself a little upon this affair; perhaps you may have forgot.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Ay, Sir, recollect yourself; pray don't be positive.

sp.speaker: Shatterbrain.
sp.p: Well, Sir, I won't be positive&emdash;but you'll permit me to say, that, to the best of my knowledge, I am no more married to your daughter than I am to the empress of Russia.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Here is my daughter&emdash;I suppose, if it is so, she will remember it, tho' you can't.

div.head: Scene XIV
div.stage: Shatterbrain, Mrs. Junket, Miss Frolick, Slang, Coxcomb, Doctor Gruel, Flavia, and afterwards Welldon.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Flavia, I hear you have been married since I went out, is it true?

sp.speaker: Flavia.
sp.p: Yes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: There now, Sir!

sp.speaker: Shatterbrain.
sp.p: Are you sure you ahve been married, Madam?

sp.speaker: Flavia.
sp.p: Very sure, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: What do you say to that, Sir?

sp.speaker: Shatterbrain.
sp.p: Nothing, Sir, only it has escaped my memory&emdash;that's all.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Still in the same strain, Look'e, Mr, Shatterbrain, I have passed by a very singular piece of your behaviour to day already, imputing it to absence of mind, or I know not what; but this is too gross to be alledged to the same cause; 'tis a public affront both to me and my daughter, and as such I shall esteem it; however, to satisfy the company&emdash;who waits there&emdash;desire Mr. Supple to step up here.

sp.speaker: Flavia.
sp.p: Come back&emdash;I am indeed married.&emdash;

sp.speaker: Welldon.
sp.p: But not to Mr. Shatterbrain, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: How!

sp.speaker: Shatterbrain.
sp.p: I hope you are convinc'd now, Sir, that I was in the right&emdash;Damn it, I knew I could not be mistaken.

sp.speaker: Flavia.
sp.p: Dear Sir, pardon my first offence, and give us your blessing ?

sp.speaker: Slang.
sp.p: Now the murder's out.

sp.speaker: Flavia.
sp.p: Can you refuse us your blesiing, when We ask it on our knees?

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Pho, pho, stand up, I take it for granted your name is Welldon.

sp.speaker: Welldon.
sp.p: That is my name, Sir.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Ungrateful girl&emdash;by what means have you carried on this intrigue? by what means brought it to this end? But don't give yourself the trouble to answer me, for I have done with you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: Shatterbrain!

sp.speaker: Shatterbrain.
sp.p: Hah!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: What are you thinking of.

sp.speaker: Shatterbrain.
sp.p: Upon my life I cannot say.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: I never knew you otherwise: but pray rouse a little, you are a party concerned, here are a young couple in distress, and they expect you will make use of your intrest in their favour.

sp.speaker: Shatterbrain.
sp.p: That I will, with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: I beg you may not, Sir, for the ill treatment you have met with, is one of my chieftest causes of anger.

sp.speaker: Shatterbrain.
sp.p: Is it, why then to shew you that I don't harbour the least resentment upon that account; here, Mr. Welldon, take this young lady (giving him Doctor Gruel's hand by mistake) whatever right and title I was like to have in her, I freely resign to you.

sp.speaker: Slang.
sp.p: Give you joy.

sp.speaker: Coxcomb.
sp.p: Joy, Madam.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: This is very generous of you, Sir.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: If you think so why don't you follow his example.

div.head: Scene XIVAgain, the scene numbering is incorrect. This should be scene fifteen.

stage.hi: Shatterbrain, Mrs. Junket, Miss Frolick, Slang, Coxcomn, Doctor Gruel, Flavia, Welldon, Robin.

sp.speaker: Robin.
sp.p: Mr. Shatterbrain, here's your servant has brought your gown and slippcrs.

sp.speaker: Shatterbrain.
sp.p: Well, let him leave them.

sp.speaker: Slang.
sp.p: Leave them, for what?

sp.speaker: Shatterbrain.
sp.p: Pho, pho, I mean lwt him take them back again.

sp.speaker: Miss Frolick.
sp.p: Come, Doctor, won't you forgive them? I shan't love you else.

sp.speaker: Doctor.
sp.p: Well, Madam, 'tis more than they deserve; however,children,since it must be so, Heaven bless you, and make you happy together.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Junket.
sp.p: And now I think we have nothing to do, but go in, and order supper as quick as possible, do, my dear Flavia, order supper as, soon as you can, for I am starving with hunger.

sp.speaker: Shatterbrain.
sp.p: Ay! Come, let's in to supper.

p.l: But hold&emdash;I had something or other to say,
Hiss our Farce, if you lik'd&emdash;hiss! No clap&emdash;marry rot it
In short, guess my meaning, for I have forgot it.

div.head: The Play
div.p: The 1768 play/adaptation of The Absent Man: a Farce was printed in quarto format (and presumably published) by William Griffin, and though the text’s authorship is left anonymous, the play is attributed to Isaac Bickerstaff, a pseudonym used by Jonathan Swift. The premise of the play is based on the character Menalcas that appears in Jean de La Bruyère’s Les Caractères de Théophraste traduits du grec avec Les Caractères ou les moeurs de ce siècle (English title: Characters, or the Manners of the Age: With the Moral Characters of Theophrastus). Menalcas appears in the seventh paragraph in the chapter titled “XI. Of Mankind.” The quarto in this digital edition contains a stamped title page, a dedication to the king (from William Griffin?), a preface, a prologue by the author of the play, a dramatis personae, and the two act play itself (and all of its dialogue, stage directions, and scene and act markers and changes). They play was performed by His Majesty’s Servants at the Theater Royal in Drury-Lane.

div.head: The Project
div.p: The Absent Man project was created as a collaborative effort between Andreas Bassett and Sarah Moore, under the direction of Dr. Geoff Turnovsky and the ENGL501 Textual Studies and Digital Editing course during the Autumn 2019 quarter at the University of Washington. Our project is a online critical edition of The Absent Man: A Farce, a 1768 theatrical adaptation of Jean de la Bruyère’s Les Charactères. Our project is designed to meet the needs of general reader, students, and researchers interested in engaging in an obscure work influenced by La Bruyère’s Les Charactères. This edition is informed by the idea of close reading and textual enfolding, that is, that meaning is created as a text reveals or obscures information. To that end, this digital project is built around the concept of curating selections of the text to interact with. Users can, for example, choose to only see dialogue spoken by specific characters, or focus on specific scenes. Users can also hide or reveal textual and critical notes. In this way, The Absent Man mimics the separate-but- related character sketches of Les Charactères.

div.head: Development Team
div.p: Andreas Bassettis a second-year doctoral student at the University of Washington, Seattle where he studies early modern drama and medieval literature. His research interests include the Shakespeare apocrypha, print culture, bibliography, stylometry, the Matter of Britain, and some of the lesser-known dramatists of the Elizabethan era. At the moment Andreas is working on his master’s essay which traces, historicizes, and analyzes three apocryphal plays by the obscure “W. S.,” Locrine (1595), Thomas Lord Cromwell (1602), and The Puritan (1607), a tragedy, history, and comedy, respectively, as an independent and cohesive trilogy. He is also currently working on developing an authoritative digital edition of Nostradamus’ Les Prophecies.

Sarah Nickel Mooreis currently a doctorate student at the University of Washington, where she studies late medieval romance and early modern drama. She has an interest in the environmental humanities and the materiality of textual manuscripts, and as such several of her past projects have focused on the connections between animal, women, and text. Currently, Sarah is completing a certificate in textual studies, in which she is applying her knowledge of the material text to the creation of digital editions. She received her master’s degree from the University of Alabama in Huntsville, with thesis work that examined the animal and female bodies in The Avowyng of Arthur and Marie de France’s Yonec. Sarah continuously seeks to improve her pedagogy, and has repeatedly used her research as a means of sparking discussion in the classroom, where she aims to help students find their critical voices.
